awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Measurement and Modeling of Brown Carbon (BrC) from Boreal Forest Wildfires in Alaska
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on characterizing the emissions, optical properties and radiative impacts of brown carbon (BrC) from biomass burning in the Arctic.  The hypothesis is that BrC in the Arctic is different because boreal forest fires tend to be smoldering due to the large consumption of below-ground biomass, and the photochemical processing of aerosol in the Arctic is slower due to the strong UV absorption by stratospheric ozone (longer light path).  The improved understanding of the properties of BrC found in the Arctic will enable chemical transport modeling to better assess the direct radiative effects of BrC from boreal forest fires.

The research will focus on three topics: (1) the emissions and optical properties of BrC from boreal forest fires; (2) the emissions and physical properties of organic aerosol and black carbon in the Arctic; and (3) the influence of Arctic biomass burning on the radiative budget at the surface.  The project includes both a measurement and a modeling component.  Data collected in this project data will be compared with that from two long-term monitoring networks with sites in the Arctic, the IMPROVE network and the Chemical Speciation Network.  The results of the project will be shared with the Alaska Fire Science Consortium, based at University of Alaska Fairbanks, to help disseminate the results to the interagency fire management community in the state.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to investigate the properties of brown carbon from boreal forest fires at Northern high latitude. We conducted extensive fieldwork in Fairbanks, Alaska, analyzing both the chemical and physical properties of brown carbon in wildfire emissions during fire seasons. These findings contribute to a deeper understanding of how wildfires affect radiative forcing through smoke particles, which is critical for predicting climate impacts. To date, we have published three peer-reviewed papers based on this research, with additional publications forthcoming.

Beyond the scientific outcomes, this project provided valuable training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students. Notably, graduate student Kunal Bali published his first paper on the measurement of brown carbon, while undergraduate Nicole June contributed a paper on modeling its properties. Our outreach efforts included delivering invited seminars and presentations at national conferences on the topic of brown carbon from boreal forest fires.

The broader impacts of the project extend to improving our understanding of the role that boreal forest fires play in the Earth system on a global scale. This knowledge will assist other researchers in predicting future climate and air quality changes in a rapidly changing environment. Additionally, the project fostered collaboration between the University of Alaska Fairbanks and several other institutions, including the Desert Research Institute, University of Nevada Las Vegas, and Florida State University, opening new pathways for community engagement and interdisciplinary research.
